case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 258-259 of 59 and 404 of 60

facts.text: These are Civil Appeals Nos. 258-259 of 59 and 404 of 60.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 258-259 of 59 and 404 of 60.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgments and orders dated July 2, 1956, January 9, 1957 and June 16, 1958 of Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated July 2, 1956, January 9, 1957 and June 16,1958 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1471, 1527 and 2990 of 56 and 1431 of 1958 respectively.

facts.text: Judgments and orders of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1471, 1527 and 2990 of 56 and 1431 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1471, 1527 and 2990 of 56 and 1431 of 1958 respectively.

facts.text: Landlords filed applications to authorities under Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 for possession of lands held by tenants.

anchor.surface_text: whose applications to the authorities under the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 for possession of the lands held by their tenants, on the grounds had that the tenancy had been terminated by due numberices on the tenants failure to pay rents for three years, were dismissed.

facts.text: Tenants failed to pay rents for three years.

anchor.surface_text: tenants failure to pay rents for three years, were dismissed.

facts.text: Tenancy terminated by due notices on tenants' failure to pay rents for three years.

anchor.surface_text: for possession of the lands held by their tenants, on the grounds had that the tenancy had been terminated by due numberices on the tenants failure to pay rents for three years, were dismissed.

facts.text: Applications dismissed by authorities.

anchor.surface_text: were dismissed.

facts.text: In three cases, authorities refused possession because tenants paid arrears or given time on equitable principles.

anchor.surface_text: These authorities refused in three of these cases to make an order for possession either because the tenants had paid up all rent which had fallen in arrear or because the authorities thought it proper on the facts of the case to give them time to pay up. They felt that the tenants were entitled to relief against forfeiture on equitable principles.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 259 of 1959, held no default in payment of rent for three years, tenant entitled to s.25 relief.

anchor.surface_text: In the fourth case, which is companyered by Civil Appeal No. 259 of 1959, it was held that there had number been on the facts of the case, default in payment of rent for three years and, therefore the tenant was entitled to statutory relief against eviction under s. 25 1  of the Act

facts.text: Bombay High Court refused to interfere under Art. 227 by summary order without reasons.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court at Bombay by a summary order, without stating any reasons, refused to interfere when moved under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Landlords filed appeals to Supreme Court with leave.

anchor.surface_text: The landlords have therefore filed these appeals with leave of this Court.

facts.text: Tenants in default in paying rents for three years within s.14(1)(a)(i), not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute in these cases that the tenants were in default in paying rents for three years within s. 14 1  a  i  and due numberices had been served by the landlords terminating the tenancies as required by the proviso to s. 14 1 .

facts.text: Due notices served by landlords terminating tenancies, not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: due numberices had been served by the landlords terminating the tenancies as required by the proviso to s. 14 1 .

facts.text: Date fixed for rent payment in s.14(1)(a)(i) is 20th March each year.

anchor.surface_text: The date fixed mentioned in s. 14 1  a  i  is it may be stated the 20th of March of each year.

facts.text: Tenancies terminated under s.14, no controversy.

anchor.surface_text: In these three cases there is numbercontroversy that the tenancies have been terminated under s.

facts.text: Tenants not entitled to relief under s.25(1) due to three years default, no dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There is also numberdispute that the tenants are number entitled to be relieved against that termination under sub-s.  1  of s. 25 because of the provisions of sub-sec.  2  of that section, as in these cases the rent had number been paid for three years.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 1, 1961 by SARKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. December 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-

facts.text: In CA 259/59, Revenue Tribunal held prior relief under s.25(1) means default merged, not countable for s.25(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Tribunal, following a decision of the High Court at Bombay in Special Civil Application No. 2073 of 1955, unreported, held that where a landlord made an application for possession of the demised land on the failure of the tenant to pay rent for a year within the time prescribed in s. 14, and the Mamlatdar granted relief to the tenant under s. 25 1 , the default was merged in the order of the Mamlatdar

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside orders refusing possession to landlords.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, companye to the companyclusion that these appeals must succeed. We set aside the orders of the High Court in the cases in which that Court had been moved and of the Revenue Tribunal and other authorities under the Bombay Act refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlords.

facts.text: Supreme Court directs respondent tenants to hand over possession to landlords.

anchor.surface_text: We direct that the respondent tenants make over possession of the lands held by them to their respective landlords.

facts.text: Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 applies.

under Art. 227 of the Constitution. The landlords have therefore filed these appeals with leave of this Court.

issues.text: Whether the authorities under the Bombay Tenancy Act can grant relief to tenants against termination of tenancy and ejectment on equitable principles of relief against forfeiture for non-payment of rent, where s.25(2) excludes statutory relief due to three years' default

anchor.surface_text: The authorities under the Act have granted them the relief by applying this equitable principle. In our opinion, the authorities were clearly in error in thinking that they companyld grant relief in these cases on equitable principles. In equity relief may be granted to a tenant who has incurred a forfeiture under the terms of the tenancy, that is, his companytract with the landlord. Here, that is number the position. The tenancies have been terminated in these cases under a statutory provision.

issues.text: Whether s.29(3) of the Bombay Tenancy Act confers on the Mamlatdar discretion to refuse an order for possession to the landlord based on the justice of the case or equitable considerations, even where the landlord has a statutory right under s.14 and s.25(2) bars tenant relief

anchor.surface_text: It was then said that s. 29 3  gives ample power to the authorities to refuse to make an order for possession in the landlords favour if the tenant pays up the arrears and the justice of the case requires that the tenant should number be deprived of the land. That sub-section numberdoubt says that the Mamlatdar shallpass such order thereon as he deems fit.

issues.text: Whether tenants are entitled to relief against forfeiture under s.114 of the Transfer of Property Act in proceedings under the Bombay Tenancy Act for termination under s.14 and exclusion under s.25(2)

anchor.surface_text: One other argument under a similar head as dealt with previously, was that the tenants were entitled to relief against forfeiture under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act. Section 3 of the Act provides that the provisions of Chapter 5

issues.text: Whether, for the purposes of s.25(2) of the Bombay Tenancy Act, a tenant is to be considered as having failed to pay rent for any year in respect of which he had been granted relief under s.25(1)

anchor.surface_text: We turn number to the remaining appeal, namely Civil Appeal No. 259 of 1959. The question raised here is whether for the purposes of s. 25 2  a tenant is to be companysidered as having failed to pay rent for any year in respect of which he had been granted relief under s. 25 1 .

anchor.surface_text: These authorities refused in three of these cases to make an order for possession either because the tenants had paid up all rent which had fallen in arrear or because the authorities thought it proper on the facts of the case to give them time to pay up. They felt that the tenants were entitled to relief against forfeiture on equitable principles.

arguments.court_reasoning: Equity applies only to contractual forfeitures, not statutory terminations under s.14; equity cannot annul statutory rights

arguments.claim: Every court of equity reluctant to enforce ejectment solely for failure to pay rent if tenant willing to pay arrears

anchor.surface_text: Every court of equity will be extremely reluctant to enforce an order of ejectment against a tenant when the only ground on which the landlord seeks ejectment is failure to pay rent. Therefore, if the tenant is willing to pay all arrears of rent, in our opinion, it would be inequitable to turn these tenants out when they are prepared to make good the arrears of rent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unable to assent to proposition so broadly put; inapplicable to statutory tenancy termination

That sub-section numberdoubt says that the Mamlatdar shallpass such order thereon as he deems fit.

arguments.claim: s.29(3) justifies refusing possession to landlord even where tenant unpaid rent for more than two years

anchor.surface_text: Before we pass on to the other appeal raising a different question, we have to refer to the case of Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar were it had been held by Chagla C.J., that s. 29 3 justifies an order granting relief to the tenant and refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlord even where the tenant has number paid rent for more than two years.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ccessive years of default but it is satisfied where the tenant has been in default for any three years. If the interpretation put by the High Court we

arguments.court_reasoning: Wrongly decided; s.25 confers substantive right on landlord; s.29(3) recognizes statutory right to possession

arguments.claim: Prior relief under s.25(1) merges default so not countable towards three years under s.25(2)

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Tribunal, following a decision of the High Court at Bombay in Special Civil Application No. 2073 of 1955, unreported, held that where a landlord made an application for possession of the demised land on the failure of the tenant to pay rent for a year within the time prescribed in s. 14, and the Mamlatdar granted relief to the tenant under s. 25 1 , the default was merged in the order of the Mamlatdar

arguments.court_reasoning: Default not wiped out or merged; relief only prevents termination effect but default remains for s.25(2) counting; purposive reading avoids undue delay for landlords

arguments.claim: No equitable relief available as tenancies terminated under statutory s.14, creating statutory right to possession

anchor.surface_text: The authorities under the Act have granted them the relief by applying this equitable principle. In our opinion, the authorities were clearly in error in thinking that they could grant relief in these cases on equitable principles. In equity relief may be granted to a tenant who has incurred a forfeiture under the terms of the tenancy, that is, his contract with the landlord. Here, that is not the position.

arguments.claim: Equity cannot relieve against provisions of a statute

anchor.surface_text: Equity does number operate to annul a statute. This appears to us to be well established but we may refer to white and Tudors Leading Cases in Equity 9th ed. p. 238, where it is stated, Although, in cases of contract between parties, equity will often relieve against penalties and forfeitures, where compensation can be granted, relief can never be given against the provisions of a statute.

arguments.claim: s.29(3) discretion confined to orders giving effect to statutory rights, not personal justice views

anchor.surface_text: We are however wholly unable to agree that this provision warrants the making of any order that the authority concerned thinks in his individual opinion that the justice of the case requires... The Justices must not omit or decline to discharge a duty according to law.

arguments.claim: Statute creates right to possession for landlord upon s.14 termination, enforceable under s.29(2)

anchor.surface_text: First, we have to point out that the tenancy having been terminated in terms of the statute, the statute would necessarily create a right in the landlord to obtain possession of the demised premises... The statute having provided for the termination of the tenancy would by necessary implication create a right in the landlord to recover possession.

arguments.claim: s.25 limits relief to specified cases; no other relief available, giving landlord right where s.25(1) unavailable

anchor.surface_text: s. 29 3 cannot be read as conferring on the authorities a power to annul this intendment of the Act. The words in lieu of making an order for ejectment in sub-s. 1 of s. 25 support the view that the Act intends that except in the circumstances mentioned in it, the landlord is entitled as of right to get an order for possession from the Mamlatdar.

arguments.claim: s.114 TP Act inconsistent with Bombay Act s.25, hence inapplicable to these tenancies per s.3

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the provisions in s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act are inconsistent with the provisions of the Bombay and cannot, therefore, under s. 3 of the latter Act govern the tenancies to which it applies. We have earlier stated that the Bombay Act clearly intended that relief against termination of tenancy for non-payment of rent would be given only in the cases mentioned in s. 25 1 and in no others.

arguments.claim: In CA 259/59, default for year with prior s.25(1) relief still counts as failure to pay under s.25(2)

holdings.text: The authorities were clearly in error in thinking that they could grant relief in these cases on equitable principles because the tenancies have been terminated under a statutory provision, and equity does not operate to annul a statute.

anchor.surface_text: The authorities under the Act have granted them the relief by applying this equitable principle. In our opinion, the authorities were clearly in error in thinking that they could grant relief in these cases on equitable principles. In equity relief may be granted to a tenant who has incurred a forfeiture under the terms of the tenancy, that is, his contract with the landlord. Here, that is not the position. The tenancies have been terminated in these cases under a statutory provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity applies to contractual forfeitures, not statutory terminations under s.14; statutory right to possession created; equity cannot override statute, citing White & Tudor's Leading Cases.

holdings.text: Section 29(3) does not warrant the making of any order that the authority concerned thinks in his individual opinion that the justice of the case requires; discretion limited to giving effect to statutory rights.

anchor.surface_text: It was then said that s. 29 3  gives ample power to the authorities to refuse to make an order for possession in the landlords favour if the tenant pays up the arrears and the justice of the case requires that the tenant should not be deprived of the land. That sub-section no doubt says that the Mamlatdar shallpass such order thereon as he deems fit. We are however wholly unable to agree that this provision warrants the making of any order that the authority concerned thinks in his individual opinion that the justice of the case requires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion confined by statute; authorities cannot refuse statutory right based on hardship; citing R. Boteler on limits of judicial discretion.

holdings.text: Upon termination of tenancy under s.14 and where s.25(1) relief unavailable due to three years default, the landlord has a statutory right to possession enforceable under s.29.

anchor.surface_text: First, we have to point out that the tenancy having been terminated in terms of the statute, the statute would necessarily create a right in the landlord to obtain possession of the demised premises. The tenancy having been terminated, the tenant is not entitled to remain in possession and the only person who would then be entitled to possession would be the landlord.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute implies right to possession post-termination; s.25 limits relief exhaustively; s.29(3) implements statutory intendment, not equity; harmonious construction.

holdings.text: Tenants not entitled to relief against forfeiture under s.114 of the Transfer of Property Act as it is inconsistent with Bombay Tenancy Act s.25 and inapplicable per s.3.

anchor.surface_text: One other argument under a similar head as dealt with previously, was that the tenants were entitled to relief against forfeiture under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act. ... In our view, the provisions in s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act are inconsistent with the provisions of the Bombay and cannot, therefore, under s. 3 of the latter Act govern the tenancies to which it applies.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.114 allows broader relief than s.25; inconsistent hence excluded by s.3 Bombay Act; no need to decide s.117 exemption.

holdings.text: Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar was wrongly decided; s.25 confers substantive right on landlord, s.29(3) recognizes it.

anchor.surface_text: Before we pass on to the other appeal raising a different question, we have to refer to the case of Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar were it had been held by Chagla C.J., that s. 29  3  justifies an order granting relief to the tenant and refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlord even where the tenant has not paid rent for more than two years. We think that this case was wrongly decided.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25 gives substantive right to possession where applicable; s.29(3) enforces it, contra to prior High Court view.

holdings.text: For purposes of s.25(2), a tenant who received prior relief under s.25(1) is still considered as having failed to pay rent for that year; default not merged or wiped out.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: relief against consequence, not default itself; purposive: avoids delaying landlord recovery; rejects merger theory.

holdings.text: The appeals succeed; orders of High Court, Revenue Tribunal, and authorities refusing possession set aside; respondent tenants to deliver possession to landlords.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above holdings to facts; statutory rights enforced.

precedents.citation: Sitaram Vithal Chitnis v. Gundu Satyappa Dhade, Special Civil Application No. 1695 of 1955, unreported

anchor.surface_text: Sitaram Vithal Chitnis v. Gundu Satyappa Dhade, Special Civil Application No. 1695 of 1955, unreported, which we quote here Every court of equity will be extremely reluctant to enforce an order of ejectment against a tenant when the only ground on which the landlord seeks ejectment is failure to pay rent. Therefore, if the tenant is willing to pay all arrears of rent, in our opinion, it would be inequitable to turn these tenants out when they are prepared to make good the arrears of rent.

precedents.case_name: Sitaram Vithal Chitnis v. Gundu Satyappa Dhade
precedents.cited_proposition: Court of equity reluctant to enforce ejectment for non-payment of rent if tenant willing to pay arrears; inequitable to evict
precedents.cited_holding: Every court of equity will be extremely reluctant to enforce an order of ejectment against a tenant when the only ground on which the landlord seeks ejectment is failure to pay rent. Therefore, if the tenant is willing to pay all arrears of rent, in our opinion, it would be inequitable to turn these tenants out when they are prepared to make good the arrears of rent.

anchor.surface_text: R. Boteler where a statute which conferred power upon Justices to issue a distress warrant if they shall think fit was considered. In that case the Justices had refused to issue the distress warrant. Cockburn C. J. observed, They went upon the ground that the introduction of this extra-parochial place into the union was a thing unjust in itself in other words, that the operation of the act of parliament was unjustI think, therefore it amounts virtually to saying,-We know that we ought upon all other grounds to issue the warrant, but we will take upon ourselves to say that the law is unjust, and we will not carry out the law.

precedents.cited_proposition: Judicial authorities cannot refuse to exercise statutory discretion on grounds that the law is unjust; must follow the law
precedents.cited_holding: They went upon the ground that ... That is not such an exercise of discretion as this Court will hold ... to be one upon which it will act. The Justices must not omit or decline to discharge a duty according to law.

precedents.citation: Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar

anchor.surface_text: Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar were it had been held by Chagla C.J., that s. 29 3 justifies an order granting relief to the tenant and refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlord even where the tenant has not paid rent for more than two years. We think that this case was wrongly decided.

precedents.case_name: Raghuvir Vyasaraya Acharya v. Gobind Mogre Bandekar
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 29(3) confers discretion on Mamlatdar to grant relief to tenant refusing possession to landlord even after three years default in rent

precedents.citation: Special Civil Application No. 2073 of 1955, unreported

anchor.surface_text: Special Civil Application No. 2073 of 1955, unreported, held that where a landlord made an application for possession of the demised land on the failure of the tenant to pay rent for a year within the time prescribed in s. 14, and the Mamlatdar granted relief to the tenant under s. 25 1 , the default was merged in the order of the Mamlatdar and could not thereafter be relied upon for the purposes of s. 25 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Default in rent payment for which relief granted under s.25(1) merges in the order and cannot count towards the three years under s.25(2)

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, come to the conclusion that these appeals must succeed. We set aside the orders of the High Court in the cases in which that Court had been moved and of the Revenue Tribunal and other authorities under the Bombay Act refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlords.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals allowed. Orders of High Court, Revenue Tribunal and authorities under Bombay Tenancy Act set aside. Respondent tenants directed to hand over possession of lands to appellant landlords.
directions: Respondent tenants make over possession of the lands held by them to their respective landlords

anchor.surface_text: The authorities under the Act have granted them the relief by applying this equitable principle. In our opinion, the authorities were clearly in error in thinking that they could grant relief in these cases on equitable principles. In equity relief may be granted to a tenant who has incurred a forfeiture under the terms of the tenancy, that is, his contract with the landlord. Here, that is not the position. The tenancies have been terminated in these cases under a statutory provision.

We, therefore, come to the conclusion that these appeals must succeed. We set aside the orders of the High Court in the cases in which that Court had been moved and of the Revenue Tribunal and other authorities under the Bombay Act refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlords.
because it is the statute which fixes the term of the tenancy and also provides for its termination it is number a companytractual right which may be

edges.explanation: The holding directly addresses and resolves the issue by ruling that s.29(3) does not confer discretion to refuse possession based on individual notions of justice or equity, limiting it to the statutory scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It was then said that s. 29 3  gives ample power to the authorities to refuse to make an order for possession in the landlords favour if the tenant pays up the arrears and the justice of the case requires that the tenant should not be deprived of the land. That sub-section no doubt says that the Mamlatdar shallpass such order thereon as he deems fit. We are however wholly unable to agree that this provision warrants the making of any order that the authority concerned thinks in his individual opinion that the justice of the case requires.

We, therefore, come to the conclusion that these appeals must succeed. We set aside the orders of the High Court in the cases in which that Court had been moved and of the Revenue Tribunal and other authorities under the Bombay Act refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlords.

anchor.surface_text: First, we have to point out that the tenancy having been terminated in terms of the statute, the statute would necessarily create a right in the landlord to obtain possession of the demised premises. The tenancy having been terminated, the tenant is not entitled to remain in possession and the only person who would then be entitled to possession would be the landlord.

We, therefore, come to the conclusion that these appeals must succeed. We set aside the orders of the High Court in the cases in which that Court had been moved and of the Revenue Tribunal and other authorities under the Bombay Act refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlords.

anchor.surface_text: One other argument under a similar head as dealt with previously, was that the tenants were entitled to relief against forfeiture under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act. ... In our view, the provisions in s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act are inconsistent with the provisions of the Bombay and cannot, therefore, under s. 3 of the latter Act govern the tenancies to which it applies.

We, therefore, come to the conclusion that these appeals must succeed. We set aside the orders of the High Court in the cases in which that Court had been moved and of the Revenue Tribunal and other authorities under the Bombay Act refusing to make an order for possession in favour of the landlords.
